qas.question: Who argues that the fundamental laws of physics are laws of temporal evolution?
Maudlin argues that the passage of time is what kind of asymmetry?
What grounds the distinction between sequences?
Whose suggestion is difficult to assess in regards to the direction of time?
Who says that the laws of physics are not laws of temporal evolution?
What does Maudlin claim time is not in the structure of the world?

plausible_answers.text: the distinction between sequences that runs from past to future and sequences which run from future to past

qas.question: What does the symetry in the temoral structure of the world ground?

context: One recent proponent of the laws solution is <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>Tim Maudlin<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> who argues that the fundamental laws of physics are laws of temporal evolution (see Maudlin ). However, elsewhere Maudlin argues: "[the] passage of time is <b6_0>an <a1_0>intrinsic<a1_0/> <a2_0>asymmetry<b6_0/><a2_0/> in the temporal structure of the world... It is the asymmetry that grounds <b7_0>the distinction between sequences that runs from past to future and sequences which run from future to past<b7_0/>" [ibid, 2010 edition, p. 108]. Thus it is arguably difficult to assess whether <a3_0>Maudlin<a3_0/> is suggesting that the direction of time is a consequence of the laws or is itself primitive.
